newsitem.title: UK: London gold, silver firmer, watching U.S. rates.
newsitem.headline: London gold, silver firmer, watching U.S. rates.

text.p: The precious metals were mostly firmer on Tuesday as the market focused on expectations of a U.S. interest rate rise later in the day, dealers said. The exception was palladium, which edged lower and fixed at at a fresh three-year low of $116.50 an ounce, down $0.25 from the previous fixing.
Gold bullion, however, fixed at $381.60 an ounce, up $0.60 from Monday's afternoon fixing. Dealers said it had found a comfortable groove in the centre of the $380-$385 range.
"Gold has found support at $381-$382. But I don't think it's out of the mire yet," a dealer said.
The market was looking for direction from the U.S. Federal Open Market Committee meeting, which dealers expected to raise short-term interest rates by one quarter percentage point.
But opinions were mixed as to whether or not an interest rate rise, which would increase the holding costs of gold, would have much of an effect on the market.
"The expectations are for a modest rise. I think it's been built into the prices so we're not exactly waiting with bated breath," one dealer said.
Stock and currency markets were holding their breath until after the FOMC's decision, which would not be known until after European trading was over.
Precious metals prices headed south late last week when U.S. investment funds launched a speculative play. Silver was the worst hit, plummeting below the key $5.00 an ounce level.
Dealers and analysts said prices were likely to move sideways for at time, or even edge higher, before shifting lower again if the funds had another go at the downside.

Silver, like gold, regained some lost ground. It was four cents higher than Monday's close, at $4.93 an ounce. "Silver seems to have found a little favour at these lower levels, but it may not be ready to bounce to $5.00 yet," a dealer said.
Platinum bounced up $1.50 to $388.00 an ounce, after fixing at a fresh 2-1/2 year low on Monday.
But palladium remained vulnerable since sliding below its $120 an ounce support level last week.
